image.altText: Qantas CEO Alan Joyce speaks to the media during a press conference.

items.synopsis: Embattled Qantas boss Alan Joyce brings his retirement forward by two months after a horror period for the airline.

title.children: Alan Joyce to leave Qantas early after tumultuous week and 'many ups and downs' to make room for 'renewal'

image.altText: The tail of a Qantas plane in front of a Qantas shed on a tarmac at an airport.

items.synopsis: Qantas boss Alan Joyce has announced he will leave the airline tomorrow, bringing forward his planned retirement by two months. Follow live.

title.children: Qantas boss to leave tomorrow, bringing forward retirement by two months, local markets open lower

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ASX 200 index -0.5%) is trading lower as banks and commodity stocks pull down the market ahead of the RBA's latest decision on interest rates. The RBA is expected to stay on hold at 4.1 per cent. Most sectors are in the red with utilities, energy, and miners leading the losses. Mineral explorer Chalice Mining is taking a hit amid the fallout from its over optimistic assessment of commodity prices for its Julimar nickel-copper project. Stockbroker Jefferies has downgraded the explorer from hold to underperform saying that the "unattractive economics" of Juliimar are not yet fully factored into the share price. And this burn: "Assumed commodity prices for the valuation of the project did not represent the common practice of using consensus or lower to validate a project's robust economics." And Qantas (+0.4%) is higher after Alan Joyce stepped down. Top movers: BrainChip: +3.2% Iress: 2.4% Megaport: +1.6% Chalice Mining: -17.2% West African Resources: -4.7% Bellevue Gold: -4.4%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX in the red at midday

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: That's the view of veteran aviation analyst Geoffrey Thomas about Alan Joyce's early departure as the boss of Qantas. Qantas announced this morning that Mr Joyce would bring forward his retirement by two months to help the company "accelerate its renewal" after a turbulent week for the airline. That includes a lawsuit by the competition regulator which alleges that Qantas sold tickets that had been cancelled. Mr Thomas told ABC News Channel that it was time for Mr Joyce to go. "He's the face of the airline." "And he's been a lightning rod for all the problems of the airline." "And so, with the latest ACCC allegations which have been brought into court, I think it was time for Alan to move on simply so that the focus could be taken away from him and let the airline deal with the issues it has to, without him being the focal point of all the criticism." Mr Thomas also thinks the Qantas board will take a look at Mr Joyce's multi million dollar salary and considering docking some of his bonuses. "These bonuses are eye-watering, particularly when the airline is having all these problems and passengers' flights have been disrupted, there's all sorts of allegations flying around." "I'm sure the board and the shareholders will look at the remuneration and they may make some adjustments to it." He says the new chief executive Vanessa Hudson faces alot of issues including updating the Qantas fleet. "Vanessa Hudson - who is now the CEO as of tomorrow - is the person who guided Qantas through the COVID pandemic, and she will be focused on shareholder value." "So the challenge for Vanessa going forward will be to maintain shareholder value while competing against airlines that either are government-owned or have far, far lower labour costs, like Indonesia." "And also, she has to oversee the biggest fleet overhaul Qantas has ever had." "That's going to be very challenging over the next three years." "So there's lots of obstacles for her."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Time for Alan to move on'

children.content: That's the view of veteran aviation analyst
about Alan Joyce's early departure as the boss of Qantas.
Qantas announced this morning that Mr Joyce would bring forward his retirement by two months to help the company "accelerate its renewal" after a turbulent week for the airline.
That includes a lawsuit by the competition regulator which alleges that Qantas sold tickets that had been cancelled.
Mr Thomas told ABC News Channel that it was time for Mr Joyce to go.
"And he's been a lightning rod for all the problems of the airline."

"And so, with the latest ACCC allegations which have been brought into court, I think it was time for Alan to move on simply so that the focus could be taken away from him and let the airline deal with the issues it has to, without him being the focal point of all the criticism."
Mr Thomas also thinks the Qantas board will take a look at Mr Joyce's multi million dollar salary and considering docking some of his bonuses.
"These bonuses are eye-watering, particularly when the airline is having all these problems and passengers' flights have been disrupted, there's all sorts of allegations flying around."
"I'm sure the board and the shareholders will look at the remuneration and they may make some adjustments to it."
He says the new chief executive Vanessa Hudson faces alot of issues including updating the Qantas fleet.
"Vanessa Hudson - who is now the CEO as of tomorrow - is the person who guided Qantas through the COVID pandemic, and she will be focused on shareholder value."

"So the challenge for Vanessa going forward will be to maintain shareholder value while competing against airlines that either are government-owned or have far, far lower labour costs, like Indonesia."
"And also, she has to oversee the biggest fleet overhaul Qantas has ever had."
"That's going to be very challenging over the next three years."
"So there's lots of obstacles for her."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Qantas shares dipped -0.5% on the opening bell, after a surprise off-market announcement that CEO Alan Joyce would be stepping down two months early. However, that quickly turned around as investors digested the news, with the airline operator's shares up +1.3% to $5.72 in the first hour of trade. Don't forget you can check live updates on the major ASX indices here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What Qantas shares are doing

children.content: Qantas shares dipped -0.5% on the opening bell, after a surprise off-market announcement that CEO Alan Joyce would be stepping down two months early.
However, that quickly turned around as investors digested the news, with the airline operator's shares up +1.3% to $5.72 in the first hour of trade.
Don't forget you can check live updates on the major ASX indices here:
